mainContent.tagline: Helping you navigate, so you move one step way
mainContent.title: Your First Steps to Success in Sweden
mainContent.subtitle: A Clear Roadmap for Every Newcomer

accommodation.title: Finding Home
accommodation.intro: Perhaps you arranged temporary lodging or rented a room before arriving in Sweden and may want to move as temporary arrangements come to an end. Looking for your ideal place to stay can be a challenging task in larger cities such as Stockholm, Gothenburg and Malmö, where available housing remains relatively scarce.
accommodation.firstVsSecondHand: You can rent first-hand or second-hand in Sweden. First-hand (första hand) means you sign an agreement with the owner of the building, while second-hand (andra hand) means you sign an agreement with someone who already has the first-hand contract or has the first-hand contract on the flat.
accommodation.waitingList: To get a first-hand contract, you need to register to be put on the municipal waiting list (bostadskö) and it can take anywhere from a few years in some municipalities up to ten years for central locations in cities like Stockholm for a first-hand contract to become available.
accommodation.secondHandRisks: As a new resident, you'll probably be renting a flat from someone who qualifies in a second-hand arrangement. It is extremely important to make sure that the tenant co-operation board of the building (bostadsrättsföreningen) or the landlord has signed off on second-hand leasing. If you rent a flat from a subletter who doesn't have permission, you run the risk of being evicted (or make a long story short).

socialSecurity.title: Personnummer
socialSecurity.intro: If you live new in Sweden, the first thing you should do is register with the Swedish Tax Authority to get your social security number, also called a personal identity number or personnummer.
socialSecurity.importance: As an EU citizen, you have the right to live, work, and study in Sweden with or without a personnummer. The personnummer is a 12 digit number issued by Skatteverket. They issue it when they confirm you can support yourself and your family during your first year in Sweden. Personnummer is not only required to be a part of the social security and health care systems in Sweden, which is otherwise quite expensive to arrange through private insurance companies, but is often used as identification proof at all government offices, banks, insurances, subscriptions, collection of postal items at the post office etc.

items.savings: Proof of savings ex. Bank statement,
items.familyMembers: Number of members in the family,
items.residence: Place of residence(must be in Sweden). You can NOT apply for a personnummer while still living abroad. Neither is a holiday address enough. You must have a residential address in Sweden.
items.inPerson: You need to go in person (all the persons in the family) to an office of Skatteverket to apply for a personnummer.
items.legalId: A legal ID certificate, preferably a passport for every person applying.

identificationCard.title: Swedish ID Card
identificationCard.intro: Once you have received your Social Security number, you need to book an appointment with Swedish tax authority Skatteverket to apply for a Swedish ID card.
identificationCard.description: Anyone who is at least 13 years old and registered for population purposes in Sweden may apply to the Swedish Tax Agency for Swedish ID card. You must be able to identify yourself, in other words prove who you are, with approved ID documentation or via an attestor.

bankAccount.title: Bank Account
bankAccount.intro: In order to open a bank account, you must always be able to identify yourself.

identification.swedishDocuments: You can identify yourself with a valid Swedish identification document, such as a passport, a national identity card or a BankID. You can also identify yourself with a Swedish driving license.
identification.foreignDocuments: If you do not have Swedish identification documents, you can identify yourself with a valid foreign passport or other photo identification document that clearly shows your citizenship and is issued by an authority or some other authorized issuer. Note that the bank may request that you also present other documents.
identification.noValidDocuments: If you do not have any valid identity documents, you must be able to prove who you are and your citizenship by means of other documents issued by a competent authority.

requirements.title: Bank Account
items: A residence permit or a visa (does not apply to EU citizens)
An admission decision confirmation from your university, showing the duration of your studies
The bank is not satisfied with the identity document submitted
The bank determines that the reason given by you to open an account is inadequate
The bank, by opening an account, would be in breach of a legal regulation or directive
You have previously acted dishonestly towards the bank

beforeVisiting.title: Visiting a Bank
beforeVisiting.subtitle: Before
items: You must be able to understand the bank's questions as well as answer them.
You must also be able to understand the information that the bank gives you.
In order for a bank to understand you, you should bring such a person with you while visiting the bank.
The bank will ask you about the source of income.
Your account and other bank services must not be used by anyone else unless an agreement for this is held with the bank.
The bank may ask you additional questions or stipulate other requirements.

employment.title: For Work In Sweden
employment.afterLink: (Arbetsförmedlingen) offers support to people looking for work. You can register either online using your Bank ID or by personally visiting the nearest Arbetsförmedlingen office. Apart from arbetsförmedlingen, there are many other privately run job websites like LinkedIn, Indeed, etc. commonly used to find a job in Sweden. These websites usually include job listings and functions where you can upload your CV.

healthcare.title: Health Centre
healthcare.description: You can visit your local health centre - vårdcentral. These centres provide a starting point for most medical treatments in Sweden. The staff can help you with health related matters and write referrals - remisser, which you need in order to see a specialist.

maternity.title: Maternity Clinics
maternity.subtitle: Mother & Child Care
maternity.description: The maternity clinic (barnmorskemottagningen) is primary health care facility for pregnant women which are responsible for women's health care throughout the pregnancy and for child's health care before, during and after birth. Visits to the government maternity clinics are free, but not in case of private care.

childCare.title: Health Care Centre
childCare.subtitle: Child
childCare.description: At the child health centre or barnavårdscentralen (BVC), you can get tips about your child's development, breastfeeding, food and illnesses. When you come home after childbirth, you can contact the child health centre to make an appointment for a first meeting. The first meeting is often held at home. At the meeting, the nurse asks you about the child health centre and looks to see how your baby is doing.

costs.title: And Fees
costs.subtitle: Costs
costs.description: The costs and fees for visiting a vårdcentral vary from county to county. But the costs of a visit is usually between 100 - 300 SEK and normally free for everyone under 20. Don't forget to cancel an appointment if you don't attend as you will otherwise have to pay the full costs of the defaulted visit.

coverage.title: Is Covered?
coverage.subtitle: Costs
coverage.description: Anyone, registered as resident in Sweden, is entitled to free dental care up to and including the 31 of December of the year you turn 23. Adults on the other hand, pay a large part of their dental care costs themselves, starting on the 1 January of the year they turn 23. For asylum seekers and undocumented immigrants, you have the right to receive dental care free of charge until your 18th birthday. If you are an adult, entitled to a dental care grant of 300 or 600 SEK a year. You can save the grant for two years and use it on one occasion, but you can't save more than two grants at the time.

findDentist.title: I Find A Dentist
findDentist.subtitle: Where Do
findDentist.description: You will get a list with all the dentists affiliated with the public dental service – Folktandvården.

drivingLicense.title: Driving License
drivingLicense.euLicense: In case you have a driving license issued by any EU country then it is valid throughout your stay in Sweden. You can even exchange your driving license with a Swedish license if you have permanent residency(RP).
drivingLicense.nonEuLicense: A driving license which is issued by any non-EEA country (excluding Switzerland and Japan) is valid for maximum one year in Sweden. It cannot be exchanged with a Swedish license. So if you want to continue driving in Sweden you must avail a Swedish driving license. For which you will have to complete the risk education, theoretical and practical driving exam.

steps.title: License
steps.subtitle: Steps to get a
items: Book a time for a driving test

parentalAllowance.title: Allowance

registration.title: With Försäkringskassan
registration.subtitle: Register
registration.description: You need to register with Försäkringskassan (the Swedish Social Insurance Agency) to qualify for various benefits like eg child care allowance, unemployment benefit, parental benefit, etc. Read more at www.forsakringskassan.se

parentalAllowance.details: Parental benefit/allowance is the money you receive to be able to be at home with your child instead of working, seeking work, or studying. The childcare, both the parents are entitled 480 days of leave per child in total(240 days each). 390 of these days are income-based and 90 days are at the minimum level. If you were working in Sweden during the pregnancy or at the time of childbirth, then you might get up to 80% of your salary as parental allowance otherwise a fixed minimum amount decided by the government will be paid. It is not your employer who bears the cost of your parent benefit but it is the Swedish Social Insurance Agency (Försäkringskassan) who pays it.

childCareAllowance.title: Care Allowance (Barnbidrag)
childCareAllowance.subtitle: Child
childCareAllowance.description: Children who are born in Sweden or started living in Sweden before their first birthday are entitled to receive child allowance starting from one month after their birth. The allowance is paid to both parents until the child turns 16.

education.title: School Admissions
education.preschool: Swedish preschools emphasises the importance of play in child's development. There is a great focus on basic values and individual needs such as playing together, tolerance and being considerate for others. Preschool is provided for children aged 1 to 5 years.
education.preschoolClass: The year your child turns 6, he or she can participate in a non-compulsory preschool class (sexårsverksamhet), designed to help children meet future classmates and prepare for primary school without the stress of heavy studies or homework. Swedish compulsory schooling is divided into four stages: förskalklass (preschool year or year 0), lågstadiet (years 1–3), mellanstadiet (years 4–6) and högstadiet (years 7–9).
education.compulsorySchool: From the ages of 7 to 16, all children in Sweden are required to attend the compulsory school (grundskola), where they are taught a core group of basic subjects. Families of children between aged six and thirteen are also offered out-of-school care before and after school hours called fritids.
education.freeEducation: Although preschools and after-school care are paid services, but from the age of 6 years all schooling in Sweden is free of charge and one hot meal during the day is also included. However if you want your child to study in private schools then private and international schools do exist in Sweden and there is usually a fee for such schools.

qualificationRecognition.title: Higher Education Qualifications
qualificationRecognition.ects: The European Commission has devised a system known as ECTS (European Credit Transfer System). It allows for the transfer of higher education credits between European countries. The Swedish Council for Higher Education (UHR) evaluates foreign qualifications in order to provide support for people looking for work in Sweden, people who wish to continue studying, or for employers who wish to employ someone with foreign qualifications.
qualificationRecognition.authorities: Figuring out the responsibilities of the different authorities isn't all that easy. Who is responsible for what? Whom should you turn to with your questions, applications and concerns?
qualificationRecognition.guide: This guide gives you a brief overview of the different authorities and their main responsibilities.

unemployment.title: Insurance
unemployment.overview: Payouts of unemployment insurance take two forms, a basic benefit or an income-related benefit. Registered yourself for A-kassa as soon you start your work.
unemployment.system: Unemployment insurance is not a part of the social insurance system in Sweden. Unemployment insurance is connected closely to the trade unions but it legally independent. When you start working in Sweden, investigate which unemployment insurance fund (which is known as A-Kassa) is available.
unemployment.eligibility: In order to receive an income-based benefit, you must have been a member of a voluntary unemployment insurance fund (A-kassa) for 12 months and have worked (been employed) for at least six months. In addition, some trade unions offer additional insurance against loss of income.

language.title: Courses
language.intro: Depending on the location of your stay, there are different options for learning Swedish while in the country. More information at: www.sweden.se
options: Folkuniversitetet offers Swedish courses at different levels.
Study associations also offer language courses and a wide range of other courses. See a list of study associations.

SFI courses (Swedish for Immigrants). Once you have become a resident in Sweden and have been issued a personal identity number (personnummer) you can contact your local municipality for information about.
language.sfiDescription: Swedish lessons for immigrants (SFI). SFI is basic training in the Swedish language for adults who do not have Swedish as their first language. You can study SFI full-time or part-time. The training is free of charge.

hero.title: Your Guide to Swedish Authorities & Getting Started
hero.subtitle: Understand the public agencies that support your life in Sweden and how to access essential services

intro.heading: Welcome to Sweden
intro.description: This guide covers all the main Swedish authorities that newcomers and residents may interact with. Each description explains what the authority does, why it matters, and how it may affect your life in Sweden.

authorities.name: Migrationsverket – The Swedish Migration Agency
authorities.description: Migrationsverket is the central authority for visas, residence permits, asylum, and citizenship in Sweden. They decide who is allowed to enter and stay in the country and under what conditions. For newcomers, this is usually the first point of contact when moving to Sweden, as they handle everything from work permits to family reunification cases. They also coordinate settlement support for refugees and ensure municipalities receive compensation for housing new arrivals.

authorities.name: Skatteverket – The Swedish Tax Agency
authorities.description: Skatteverket manages taxes but is equally important for personal identity and registration. Every newcomer must register with Skatteverket for folkbokföring (population registration) to get a personal identity number, which is essential for healthcare, banking, and schooling. They also issue Swedish ID cards, process tax returns, and manage family-related tax benefits. Without Skatteverket registration, access to most other public services is not possible.

authorities.name: Arbetsförmedlingen – Public Employment Service
authorities.description: Arbetsförmedlingen connects job seekers with employers and provides training, internships, and subsidized employment programs. For newcomers, they offer specialized support like language-based work introductions and programs to ease entry into the labor market. They also provide career guidance and support in developing skills needed for Swedish workplaces.

authorities.name: Arbetsmiljöverket – Work Environment Authority
authorities.description: This authority ensures that all workplaces in Sweden follow laws and regulations concerning safety, health, and fair treatment. They investigate accidents, respond to complaints about unsafe working conditions, and inspect employers. For newcomers unfamiliar with Swedish labor law, Arbetsmiljöverket is a safeguard ensuring fair treatment at work.

authorities.name: Bolagsverket – Companies Registration Office
authorities.description: Bolagsverket registers new companies, associations, and financial accounts for entrepreneurs. They ensure legal transparency for businesses by making ownership, accounting, and corporate structure public. Newcomers who want to start businesses in Sweden must interact with Bolagsverket to register properly.

authorities.name: Försäkringskassan – Social Insurance Agency
authorities.description: Försäkringskassan manages Sweden's social insurance system, providing financial support during life events such as illness, parenthood, unemployment, or disability. They pay child allowance, parental leave benefits, and housing supplements. For newcomers, registering with Försäkringskassan is essential to access these protections.

authorities.name: Kommunerna – The Municipalities
authorities.description: Each municipality is responsible for local services like housing, preschools, schools, SFI (Swedish for Immigrants), and social orientation. They also provide financial support to individuals without work and handle local welfare needs. For newcomers, municipalities are the main contact for housing support and integration services.

authorities.name: Hyresnämnden – Rent Tribunal
authorities.description: Hyresnämnden is a special court that resolves disputes between tenants and landlords. They handle issues such as rent levels, eviction threats, and apartment renovations. For newcomers, this authority ensures protection against unfair housing practices and gives a neutral platform to resolve conflicts.

authorities.name: Skolverket – National Agency for Education
authorities.description: Skolverket is responsible for curricula, teaching standards, and national exams in Swedish schools. They also process applications for foreign teachers seeking recognition. For newcomers, they help children integrate into the school system and guarantee quality education.

authorities.name: UHR – Swedish Council for Higher Education
authorities.description: UHR manages admissions to universities, evaluates foreign diplomas, and provides scholarships. They are the gateway for newcomers seeking higher education in Sweden. Their role is especially important for those wishing to transfer international qualifications into the Swedish job market.

authorities.name: CSN – National Board of Student Aid
authorities.description: CSN provides loans and grants for students in Sweden. Nearly every student interacts with CSN to finance their studies. For newcomers, CSN can provide financial independence while studying.

authorities.name: DO – Equality Ombudsman
authorities.description: DO combats discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, religion, disability, age, or sexual orientation. They provide legal support to individuals experiencing discrimination. For newcomers, DO is a key resource in defending human rights.

authorities.name: JO – Parliamentary Ombudsman
authorities.description: The Ombudsman investigates complaints of maladministration by government authorities or officials. Any resident can file a complaint if treated unfairly by an authority. For newcomers, JO ensures equal treatment and accountability in public administration.

authorities.name: Konsumentverket – Consumer Agency
authorities.description: Konsumentverket protects consumers from unfair practices, false advertising, and unsafe products. They provide information on contracts, purchases, and consumer rights. For newcomers, Konsumentverket helps when dealing with unfamiliar markets.

authorities.name: Landstingen / Regionerna – County Councils / Regions
authorities.description: Regions are responsible for public healthcare and hospitals. They provide medical services, emergency care, and preventive health programs. For newcomers, registering with your region ensures access to doctors and health services.

authorities.name: Läkemedelsverket – Medical Products Agency
authorities.description: Responsible for approving medicines, supervising pharmacies, and monitoring drug safety. They ensure medicines on the Swedish market are safe and effective. For newcomers, Läkemedelsverket protects health by regulating treatment quality.

authorities.name: Folkhälsomyndigheten – Public Health Agency
authorities.description: This agency manages disease control, vaccinations, and health promotion. They provide vital information during pandemics or health risks. For newcomers, they ensure equal protection from public health threats.

authorities.name: MSB – Civil Contingencies Agency
authorities.description: MSB coordinates Sweden's response to emergencies such as natural disasters, terrorism, or major accidents. They also promote crisis preparedness at local levels. For newcomers, MSB provides guidance on safety during unexpected events.

authorities.name: Räddningstjänsten – Local Rescue Services
authorities.description: Municipal rescue services handle fire protection, accidents, and local emergencies. For newcomers, knowing the local rescue service ensures quick help in emergencies.

numbers.details: Report crimes, ask for police assistance

emergency.title: Emergency Services
emergency.content: Call 112 for all emergencies in Sweden. Available 24/7 in multiple languages.

banks.title: Banks
banks.content:
Open a Swedish bank account for daily transactions, salary deposits and bill payments.

Providers: Swedbank, Handelsbanken, SEB, Nordea
Requirements: Personnummer, ID, proof of address
Features: English customer service, mobile banking, international transfers

Tips: Most banks offer English support and digital services

healthcare.title: Healthcare
healthcare.content: Register with local healthcare center (vårdcentral) for medical services.

driving.title: Driving License
driving.content: Convert your international driving license to Swedish license within one year.

transport.title: Public Transport
transport.content: Use SL app for Stockholm, Västtrafik for Gothenburg region transport.

languageSchool.title: Language School
languageSchool.content: Free Swedish for Immigrants (SFI) courses available nationwide.

studies.title: Higher Studies
studies.content: Swedish universities offer many programs in English at graduate level.

government.title: Government Institutes
government.content: Key offices: Skatteverket (Tax), Migrationsverket (Immigration), Försäkringskassan (Social Insurance).

housing.title: Housing
housing.content: Register for municipal housing queues early. Consider second-hand rentals initially.

employment.title: Public Employment Agency
employment.content: Arbetsförmedlingen provides job search assistance and career guidance.

systemGuide.tagline: Guiding You to the Right Support, Every Step of the Way.
systemGuide.title: Understand the System
systemGuide.subtitle: Departments- Roles and Your Rights

migrationAgency.title: The Swedish Migration Agency
migrationAgency.subtitle: Migrationsverket
migrationAgency.description: Migrationsverket is the central authority for visas, residence permits, asylum, and citizenship in Sweden. They decide who is allowed to enter and stay in the country and under what conditions. For newcomers, this is usually the first point of contact when moving to Sweden, as they handle everything from work permits to family reunification cases. They also coordinate settlement support for refugees and assure municipalities receive compensation for housing new arrivals.

taxAgency.title: The Swedish Tax Agency
taxAgency.subtitle: Skatteverket
taxAgency.description: Skatteverket manages taxes but is equally important for personal identity and registration. Every newcomer must register with Skatteverket for födelsetid (population registration) to get a personal identity number, which is essential for healthcare, banking and schooling. They also issue Swedish ID cards, process tax returns, and manage family-related tax benefits. Without Skatteverket registration, access to most other public services is not possible.

employmentService.title: Public Employment Service
employmentService.subtitle: Arbetsförmedlingen
employmentService.description: Arbetsförmedlingen connects job seekers with employers and provides training, internships, and subsidized employment programs for newcomers. They offer specialized support like language-based work introductions and programs to enter entry jobs into the labor market. They also provide career guidance and support in developing skills needed for Swedish workplaces. Their services are crucial for gaining financial independence after arrival.

workEnvironment.title: Work Environment Authority
workEnvironment.subtitle: Arbetsmiljöverket
workEnvironment.description: This authority ensures that all workplaces in Sweden follow laws and regulations concerning safety, health, and fair treatment. They investigate accidents, respond to complaints about unsafe working conditions, and inspect employers. For newcomers unfamiliar with Swedish labor law, Arbetsmiljöverket is a safeguard ensuring fair treatment at work. Their role is vital for protecting both employers and employees alike.

enforcementAuthority.title: Enforcement Authority
enforcementAuthority.subtitle: Kronofogden
enforcementAuthority.description: Kronofogden deals with debts, unpaid bills, and enforcement of court decisions. They can collect payments on behalf of creditors but provide support when overwhelmed by debt. For newcomers, understanding Kronofogden is important when dealing with contracts, rent, or loans, particularly if financial difficulties arise. They can provide permits and credit ratings. They also help mediate solutions to avoid bankruptcy or eviction.

companiesRegistration.title: Companies Registration Office
companiesRegistration.subtitle: Bolagsverket
companiesRegistration.description: Bolagsverket registers new companies, associations, and financial accounts for entrepreneurs. They ensure legal transparency for businesses by making ownership, accounting, and corporate governance public. Newcomers who want to start businesses in Sweden must interact with Bolagsverket to register properly. Their services also protect consumers by ensuring businesses are legally accountable.

economicGrowth.title: Agency for Economic & Regional Growth
economicGrowth.subtitle: Tillväxtverket
economicGrowth.description: This agency supports entrepreneurship, small and medium-sized businesses, and regional development. They offer advice, funding, and programs to encourage innovation and competitiveness. For newcomers starting companies or exploring investments, Tillväxtverket provides practical resources and guidance. Their role is central in creating economic opportunities across Sweden, including integration of migrant-owned businesses.

socialInsurance.title: Social Insurance Agency
socialInsurance.subtitle: Försäkringskassan
socialInsurance.description: Försäkringskassan manages Sweden's social insurance system, providing financial support during life events such as illness, unemployment, unemployment, or disability. They pay child allowance, parental leave benefits, and housing supplements. For newcomers, registering with Försäkringskassan is essential to access these protections. They act as a safety net ensuring that everyone legally living in Sweden has access to social security.

municipalities.title: The Municipalities
municipalities.subtitle: Kommunerna
municipalities.description: Each municipality is responsible for local services like housing, preschools, schools, SFI (Swedish for immigrants), and social orientation. They also provide financial support to individuals without work and handle local welfare needs. For newcomers, municipalities are the main contact for housing support and integration services. They also coordinate healthcare access and daily community support.

rentTribunal.title: Rent Tribunal
rentTribunal.subtitle: Hyresnämnden
rentTribunal.description: Hyresnämnden is a special court that resolves disputes between tenants and landlords. They handle issues such as rent levels, eviction threats, and apartment renovations. For newcomers, this authority ensures protection against unfair housing practices and acts as a neutral platform to resolve conflicts. Their decisions are legally binding and safeguard housing rights in Sweden.

pensionsAgency.title: Pensions Agency
pensionsAgency.subtitle: Pensionsmyndigheten
pensionsAgency.description: Bolagsverket registers new companies, associations, and financial accounts for entrepreneurs. They ensure legal transparency for businesses by making ownership, accounting, and corporate governance public. Newcomers who want to start businesses in Sweden must interact with Bolagsverket to register properly. Their services also protect consumers by ensuring businesses are legally accountable.

healthWelfare.title: National Board of Health & Welfare
healthWelfare.subtitle: Socialstyrelsen
healthWelfare.description: Socialstyrelsen supervises healthcare, social services, and elder care. They set guidelines for hospitals, social workers, and welfare providers to ensure equal quality nationwide. For newcomers, this guarantees that care is fair, accessible, and follows national standards. They also collect data to improve Swedish healthcare and social policy.

housingBuilding.title: National Board of Housing, Building & Planning
housingBuilding.subtitle: Boverket
housingBuilding.description: Boverket regulates building safety, housing standards, and city planning. They ensure housing is safe, accessible, and environmentally sustainable. For newcomers, Boverket's role is indirect but important: they safeguard housing rights by enforcing fair building regulations. Their work supports long-term housing stability in Sweden.

nationalEducation.title: National Agency for Education
nationalEducation.subtitle: Skolverket
nationalEducation.description: Skolverket is responsible for curricula, teaching standards, and national exams in Swedish schools. They also process applications for foreign teachers who want to work in Sweden. Their role helps children integrate into the school system and guarantees quality education. Their role ensures that every child has equal opportunities in Swedish education.

higherEducation.title: Swedish Council for Higher Education
higherEducation.subtitle: UHR
higherEducation.description: UHR manages admissions to universities, evaluates foreign diplomas, and provides scholarships. They are the gateway for newcomers seeking higher education in Sweden. Their role is especially important for those wishing to transfer international qualifications into the Swedish job market. They ensure fair access to higher education opportunities.

studentAid.title: National Board of Student Aid
studentAid.subtitle: CSN
studentAid.description: CSN provides loans and grants for students in Sweden. Nearly every student interacts with CSN to finance their studies. For newcomers, CSN can provide financial independence while studying. They make education more accessible and support lifelong learning.

ombudsman.title: Parliamentary Ombudsman
ombudsman.subtitle: JO
ombudsman.description: The Ombudsman investigates complaints of maladministration by government authorities or officials. Any resident can file a complaint if treated unfairly by an authority. For newcomers, JO ensures equal treatment and accountability in public administration. They are a safeguard against abuse of power.

justice.title: Chancellor of Justice
justice.subtitle: JK
justice.description: JK supervises public authorities and acts as the government's legal representative. They also handle claims for damages against the state. For newcomers, JK ensures government actions comply with Swedish law. They protect individuals against unlawful state decisions.

equality.title: Equality Ombudsman
equality.subtitle: DO
equality.description: DO combats discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, religion, disability, age, or sexual orientation. They provide legal support to individuals experiencing discrimination. DO is a key resource in defending human rights. Their mission ensures equal opportunities for everyone in Sweden.

consumer.title: Consumer Agency
consumer.subtitle: Konsumentverket
consumer.description: Konsumentverket protects consumers from unfair practices, false advertising, and unsafe products. They provide information on contracts, purchases, and consumer rights. For newcomers, Konsumentverket helps when dealing with unfamiliar markets. They promote fair business ethics throughout Sweden.

disputes.title: National Board of Student Aid
disputes.subtitle: ARN
disputes.description: ARN is a public body that resolves consumer-business disputes free of charge. Common cases include travel, electronics, and education. For newcomers, ARN offers a simple way to resolve consumer rights without going to court. Their decisions are widely respected and followed by businesses.

integrity.title: Integrity Protection Authority
integrity.subtitle: IMY
integrity.description: IMY enforces GDPR and ensures individuals' personal data is handled properly. They investigate complaints about privacy violations and ensure of digital information. For newcomers, IMY protects personal data when using banks, employers, or government services.

police.title: Police Authority
police.subtitle: Polismyndigheten
police.description: The police prevent crime, investigate offences, and maintain public safety. They also issue residence cards and passports. For newcomers, the police ensure protection and help when individual rights are violated. They ensure security and enforce the law fairly.

prosecution.title: Prosecution Authority
prosecution.subtitle: Åklagarmyndigheten
prosecution.description: This authority prosecutes crimes and leads investigations together with the police. They ensure the right to a fair legal trial. For newcomers, they guarantee equal treatment under the law. Their work guarantees fair and legal handling of criminal cases.

courts.title: National Courts Administration
courts.subtitle: Domstolsverket
courts.description: Domstolsverket administers all Swedish courts and helps provide access to civil, criminal, and administrative justice. For newcomers, Domstolsverket guarantees the right to appeal decisions. They ensure courts remain independent and accessible.

crimeVictim.title: Crime Victim Authority
crimeVictim.subtitle: Brottsoffermyndigheten
crimeVictim.description: This authority provides crime victims with support, compensation, counseling, and legal information. They help crime victims navigate the justice system. For newcomers, Brottsoffermyndigheten ensures equal access to victim support. They protect vulnerable individuals in legal proceedings.

regions.title: County Councils / Regions
regions.subtitle: Landsting / Regioner
regions.description: Regions run healthcare, dental care, and hospitals. They provide medical services, emergency care, and preventive health programs. For newcomers, registering with your region ensures access to doctors and health services. Regions guarantee healthcare for all residents.

healthInspectorate.title: Health and Social Care Inspectorate
healthInspectorate.subtitle: IVO
healthInspectorate.description: IVO supervises healthcare and social services. They investigate and handle complaints about poor treatment or unsafe practices. For newcomers, IVO ensures protection in healthcare or welfare services fail. Their role safeguards the quality of essential care.

publicHealth.title: Public Health Agency
publicHealth.subtitle: Folkhälsomyndigheten
publicHealth.description: This agency manages disease control, vaccinations, and health information. They guide and protect public health during pandemics or health risks. For newcomers, they ensure equal protection from public health threats. They advise on vaccinations, screening, and well-being.

medicalProducts.title: Medical Products Agency
medicalProducts.subtitle: Läkemedelsverket
medicalProducts.description: Responsible for approving medicines, supervising pharmacies and monitoring drug safety. They ensure medicines are Swedish market are safe and effective. For newcomers, Läkemedelsverket protects health by regulating treatment quality. They work builds trust in Swedish healthcare.

pharmacy.title: National Pharmacy Chain
pharmacy.subtitle: Apoteket
pharmacy.description: Apoteket provides prescription medicines, health advice, and over the counter products nationwide. For newcomers, Apoteket is the first stop for everyday healthcare needs. They ensure medicines are accessible and properly distributed.

transport.title: Transport Agency
transport.subtitle: Transportstyrelsen
transport.description: Manages traffic systems, vehicle rules, and transport laws. For newcomers, Transportstyrelsen is the authority for exchanging foreign licenses and following traffic rules. They ensure transport safety and compliance.

transportAdmin.title: Transport Administration
transportAdmin.subtitle: Trafikverket
transportAdmin.description: Plans, builds and maintains roads, railways, and infrastructure. For newcomers, Trafikverket provides reliable transport networks for daily life. Their work supports commuting to work and essential services.

agriculture.title: Board of Agriculture
agriculture.subtitle: Jordbruksverket
agriculture.description: Promotes sustainable animal health and food production. They regulate pet imports and agricultural products. For newcomers with pets, Jordbruksverket handles animal requirements. They promote healthy ecosystems and food safety for Sweden.

customs.title: Customs Authority
customs.subtitle: Tullverket
customs.description: Controls imports and customs duties. They prevent smuggling and illegal goods. For newcomers, Tullverket is relevant when moving belongings or receiving goods from abroad. They protect Sweden's economy and safety.

environment.title: Environmental Protection Agency
environment.subtitle: Naturvårdsverket
environment.description: Safeguards the environment, biodiversity, and natural resources. They enforce climate laws and sustainable policies. For newcomers, Naturvårdsverket ensures clean air in Stockholm. Clean and safe environment. They safeguard natural resources for future generations.

energy.title: Energy Agency
energy.subtitle: Energimyndigheten
energy.description: Promotes renewable energy, efficiency and clean energy. They provide subsidies and guidance on energy use. For newcomers, Energimyndigheten indirectly lowers energy costs for heating. They ensure sustainable, affordable, sustainable energy. They drive Sweden's green transition.

electrical.title: Electrical Safety Authority
electrical.subtitle: Elsäkerhetsverket
electrical.description: Ensures electrical products and installations are safe. They issue warnings about dangerous products and set safety rules. For newcomers, this agency guarantees safe homes and safe workplace electricity. Their role prevents accidents and ensures reliable.

telecom.title: Post and Telecom Authority
telecom.subtitle: PTS
telecom.description: Regulates network, postal services, and internet providers. They ensure consumer rights in digital and communication services. For newcomers, PTS guarantees reliable internet, mobile and postal services. They guarantee fair competition and accessibility.

civilContingencies.title: Civil Contingencies Agency
civilContingencies.subtitle: MSB
civilContingencies.description: MSB prepares Sweden for emergencies such as natural disasters, terrorism, or major accidents. They also provide crisis preparedness at local levels. For newcomers, MSB provides guidance on safety during unexpected events. They ensure Sweden is resilient against major threats.

rescueServices.title: Local Rescue Services
rescueServices.subtitle: Räddningstjänsten
rescueServices.description: Local rescue services handle fire protection, accidents, and local emergencies. For newcomers, knowing the local rescue service ensures quick help in emergencies. They work closely with police and ambulances.

coastGuard.title: Coast Guard
coastGuard.subtitle: Kustbevakningen
coastGuard.description: The Coast Guard ensures maritime safety, border protection, and environmental security at sea. For newcomers living near coasts, they handle rescue missions and pollution control. They protect both Sweden's borders and natural waters.

countyBoards.title: County Administrative Boards
countyBoards.subtitle: Länsstyrelserna
countyBoards.description: Regional bodies that implement national policy, coordinate integration, and supervise municipalities. For newcomers, they ensure housing, SFI, and orientation programs are available. They bridge national policy with local action.

election.title: Election Authority
election.subtitle: Valmyndigheten
election.description: Manages elections and ensures fair voting processes. For newcomers who become citizens, Valmyndigheten enables democratic participation. They guarantee democratic rights. They ensure indigenous voices are represented in public life.

youth.title: Youth & Civil Society Authority
youth.subtitle: MUCF
youth.description: Supports youth organizations, NGOs, and civic engagement. For newcomers, MUCF helps with opportunities to join community projects. They strengthen democratic participation and social cohesion.

sami.title: Sami Parliament
sami.subtitle: Sametinget
sami.description: Represents Sami indigenous rights, language, and culture. While not directly relevant for most newcomers, it highlights Sweden's commitment to minority rights. It ensures indigenous voices are represented in public life.

audit.title: National Audit Office
audit.subtitle: Riksrevisionen
audit.description: Riksrevisionen audits government activities and ensures accountability. For newcomers, this guarantees transparency and trust in Sweden's public finances. They protect taxpayers from misuse of funds.

statistics.title: Statistics Sweden
statistics.subtitle: SCB
statistics.description: SCB collects and analyzes data on population, economy, and society. Their data is the foundation of Sweden's policies. For newcomers, SCB explains trends that affect housing, jobs, and migration. They help society make informed decisions.

digitalGov.title: Agency for Digital Government
digitalGov.subtitle: DIGG
digitalGov.description: DIGG promotes digital transformation and online tools for authorities. For newcomers, DIGG makes it easier to access public services digitally. They promote efficiency and trust in Sweden's digital systems.

media.title: Press, Radio & TV Authority
media.subtitle: MPRT
media.description: MPRT regulates broadcasting, press, television and media licenses. For newcomers, MPRT ensures diverse and reliable access to news, entertainment, and information about their new media landscape.

cta.heading: Need Help Navigating Swedish Authorities?
cta.description: Sweden Relocators can guide you through establishing yourself in Sweden. From residence permits to personalnummer registration, we ensure a smooth transition.
cta.subtext: Authorities and regulations are subject to change. Always verify current requirements on official government websites.
